title: Lewis eyes debut in Dewey
text:
Lewis eyes debut in Dewey By Mike Tupa mtupa@examiner-enterprise.com 
Sounds like thunder, sledgehammer echoes and dynamite blasts could rattle the roof of the Washington County Fairgrounds sometime late Saturday night. 
But, there’s no reason for patrons at the nearby Dewey High School stadium to dive under the grandstands for cover, or for startled seismologists to send out an alert. 
The epicenter of Saturday’s hubbub will be about four feet above ground level — within the four corner posts of the fighting ring in the fairgrounds convention center. 
The explosive action will begin when the bell sounds to begin the kickboxing clash between athletic titans Ronnell Lewis and Mario Marino. 
Both warriors are 230-pounds-plus towers of muscle and acres of tough. 
“This will be an interesting matchup,” said Randy Rouse, who is organizing the Team Rouse Fight Night, set to start at 8 p.m. at the fairgrounds. “This will not be a cake walk for either of these guys. … I think this is going to be a clash of titans.” 
Lewis is not an unfamiliar commodity within the borders of the Sooner State. 
The 25-year-old Dewar native played twice earned Consensus All-American honors (2010, 2011) during his college football career as a linebacker at the University of Oklahoma. 
The Detroit Lions selected him in the fourth round of the 2012 NFL draft and he spent a year with the team. 
Lewis played Canadian Football League ball in 2013 and has spent time since with multiple other pro football teams, most recently with the Spokane (Wash.) Shock — which lists him on its 2016 roster as a 6-foot-3, 270-pound linebacker. 
Saturday’s fight will be his ring debut. 
“Ronnell just has got raw power,” Rouse said. “He’s got the kind of power that picks you up when he hits you. … I think Ronnell is getting everything he needs to be prepared for this. His football career shows that he is a beast. … The fight game was the next progression for him.” 
Marino is coming out of Springfield, Mo., but originally hails from the country of Columbia, Rouse said. 
Marino has blossomed by the skillful cultivation of trainer Ike Stafford, Rouse said, adding that Stafford “is one of the top coaches on the planet.” 
Rouse said he was told Marino has slimmed down from 340 pounds to 230 pounds during his time with Stafford. 
“I think Ronnell will have his hands full,” Rouse continued. “Ike said Mario is working hard and wants to be perfect. … I have no doubt this Mario is no joke.” 
Craig Blacklock — who Rouse labeled as “one of the best trainers in the United States” — is preparing Lewis for his fighting endeavors. 
“Craig told me there’s nobody with his kind of power and his kind of punches,” said Rouse. 
Rouse finds himself torn between loyalties for the bout. 
He said he feels Stafford helped open the doors for him to be able to train fighters — and also helped open the doors in Japan for Rouse. 
But, Rouse also feels closely connected to Blacklock, who he referred to as one of the next generation of top-notch trainers. 
“Somebody’s going to go home disappointed,” he said. “I don’t want to see Ronnell lose. … But, I’m nervous because I’m friends with both camps. On the flip side, the one that wins is going to earn it.” 
The fight card currently includes eight bouts, but Rouse is trying to firm up a couple of more matchups before he reveals later this week the lineup. Rules for posting comments
